Vital signs remain stable, with a temperature of 36.1Â°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 91/53 mmHg. 1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, or stroke.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure of 91/53 mmHg may indicate hypovolemia, sepsis, or cardiac failure, which can worsen if not addressed.

5. Infection: The patient's prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia may indicate a high risk of infection, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
6. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid balance of 0 mL in and out may indicate inadequate fluid management, which can lead to fluid overload, cardiac failure, or respiratory distress.

These potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent or mitigate their impact on the patient's condition.

Chief Complaint: Transfer to CCU for hypotension
   24 Hour Events: : Mr. [**Known lastname 6286**] is a 79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area
   0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF
   exacerbation and worsening of AS, who p/w persistent severe DOE  on
   [**2168-5-30**]. Please see admit note and team progress notes for more details.
   Briefly, DOE was evaluated by the team with TTE and was found to be
   likely due to critical AS with a valve area of 0.5 and gradient of 60.
   Plan was for patient to undergo aortic valvuloplasty today. Patient
   thought to be slightly overloaded due to othropnea so was given lasix
   20 mg IVx1. Patient put out 250 cc and was found on routine vitals
   check to have BP 81/52, temp 97.1, HR 103, RR 30, and 95% 4L. Patient
   triggered for hypotension as his SBP normally runs in the 110s.
   Patient as given 650 cc of NS. UA with positive Ntr, small LE, and 12
   wbc. CBC shows new leukocytosis. Started empirically on Vanco/Zosyn.
   Also of note patient has had guiac positive stools. Transferred to CCU
   for further management of critical AS.

   Gen: ill appearing, somnolent, tachypneic, originally A and OX1 but now

   HEENT: no appreciable JVD while lying flat (for hypotension)
   CV: Irregular, tachycardic, [**4-1**] harsh late peaking SEM, no rubs or

        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan:
   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty.
   # Critical AS: Recent echo showed valve area 0.5mm2, pt's current
   symptoms of severe DOE due to AS. Awaiting valvulplasty later on today.
   [**Month (only) 8**] have been overdiuresed yesterday leading to poor forward flow and
   subsequent hypotension. Although patient only put out 300 cc to lasix,
   patient did have profuse diarrhea which may have also led to volume
   shifts. BP has responded to small fluid bolus of 650 cc on the floor.
   -  Plan to hold off on further fluids. Goal MAP greater than 55.
   Peripheral dopamine if needed. Will hold on further fluids for now.
   - Plan for Valvuloplasty today
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads 2 is
   4. Was on heparin gtt on the floor but will d/c now given hct drop.
   Appears in a fib right now on tele, but rate controlled less than 100.
   -Hold heparin gtt
   -active t and s
   - 12 lead EKG now
   - Continue dofetelide
   # Sepsis: Given diarrhea, Cdiff in differential, even though C diff
   negative x1. UA points to possible urinary source. Patient had
   previously reported a cough but may have been due to over hydration.
   Patient does meet sepsis criteria with positive UA, in addition to low
   grade fever, leukocytosis, increase RR, and tachycardia. Waxing and
   [**Doctor Last Name 226**] MS may be delirium.
   - Start empiric Vanco/Zosyn
   - Follow culture data
   - Will need central access
   - repeat C diff
   # Acute renal failure: Likely due to poor forward flow in the setting
   of sepsis and critical AS.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - Urine lytes
   # Cirrhosis: - Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports that he stopped drinking
   approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well as CT abdomen. Pt
   hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. G positive stools may be due to
   upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal bleed.
   In addition EGD [**2168-6-2**] without varices. EGD did show Erythema and
   congestion in the first part of the duodenum, second part of the
   duodenum and third part of the duodenum compatible with mild
   duodenitis. Given brown stools, and Hct drop, in the setting of
   heparin, history is most consistent with likely upper source of GIB.
   -2 pivs
   -active T and S
   -Consider IV ppi
   - Consider reconsulting GI
   # DM
 ISS
   # FEN
 NPO
   # Access: PIV
   # PPx
 No heparin given ? GIB
   # Code- DNR/I
   # Communication

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS.

The patient presented with persistent severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and was found to have a valve area of 0.5cm2 with a gradient of 60, indicating critical AS. He was given lasix 20mg IV, which resulted in a 250cc output and a subsequent drop in blood pressure to 81/52mmHg. The patient was transferred to the CCU for further management.

The patient has several ongoing medical conditions, including:

1. Critical AS: The patient's symptoms of severe DOE are due to critical AS, and he is awaiting valvuloplasty later today.
2. New onset atrial fibrillation (AF): The patient was noted to be in AF on admission, and cardioversion was attempted. He is currently rate-controlled with a heart rate less than 100 beats per minute (bpm).
3. Sepsis: The patient has a positive urine analysis (UA) and is at risk for sepsis. He meets the sepsis criteria with a low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased respiratory rate, and tachycardia.
4. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's ARF is likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of cirrhosis and is likely to have consumed excessive amounts of ethanol. He has guaiac-positive stools, which may be due to upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).
6. Diabetes mellitus (DM): The patient has a history of DM.

The patient is currently receiving treatment for his conditions, including:

1. Empiric antibiotics (Vanco/Zosyn) for sepsis
2. Dopamine for potential use in treating hypotension
3. Furosemide (Lasix) for volume overload
4. Heparin for potential use in treating sepsis
5. Dofetilide for rate control in atrial fibrillation
6. Proton pump inhibitors (PPI) for potential use in treating GIB

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical AS and new onset AF increase his risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and sudden death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis increases his risk for organ failure, including renal failure, respiratory failure, and hepatic failure.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's GIB increases his risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and sepsis.
4. Renal complications: The patient's ARF increases his risk for renal failure, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
5. Hepatic complications: The patient's cirrhosis increases his risk for hepatic failure, which can lead to liver failure and death.

The patient's code status is DNR/I, and he has a first cousin who is his primary contact. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old man with critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus, was admitted with exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. He was found to have a valve area of 0.5 cm2 and a gradient of 60, leading to severe dyspnea on exertion. The patient was given lasix 20 mg IV, which resulted in a 250-cc output and subsequent hypotension. He was transferred to the CCU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Critical AS: The patient's valve area of 0.5 cm2 and gradient of 60 may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or worsening heart failure.
	* Atrial Fibrillation (AF): The patient's new-onset AF may contribute to his symptoms of severe dyspnea on exertion and may require further management.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pulmonary Edema: The patient's sCHF and hypotension may lead to pulmonary edema, which can worsen his respiratory status.
	* Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory disease and hypotension may lead to respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
3. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea may lead to electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, and further compromise his cardiac and respiratory status.
	* Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection: The patient's diarrhea and recent antibiotic use may increase his risk of developing C. diff infection.
4. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis, positive urine culture, and low-grade fever may indicate sepsis, which can worsen his cardiac and respiratory status.
	* Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient's positive urine culture may indicate a UTI, which can lead to further complications if left untreated.
5. Liver Complications:
	* Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen his cardiac and respiratory status, and may require further management and monitoring.
	* Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and hypotension may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can worsen his neurological status.
6. Renal Complications:
	* Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's hypotension and sepsis may lead to AKI, which can worsen his cardiac and respiratory status.
	* Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): The patient's underlying CKD may worsen his cardiac and respiratory status, and may require further management and monitoring.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, infection, liver, and renal complications. Close monitoring and management of these complications are essential to ensure the patient's optimal care and outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. The patient is awaiting aortic valvuloplasty today.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 97.1Â°C, heart rate 103 beats per minute, respiratory rate 30 breaths per minute, and blood pressure 81/52 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is euvolemic, and his cardiac output is likely compromised due to critical AS.
* Review of systems: The patient denies chest pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, palpitations, orthopnea, edema, and peripheral neuropathy.
* Physical examination: The patient is ill-appearing, somnolent, and tachypneic. His cardiovascular examination reveals an irregular heart rhythm, tachycardia, and a harsh late-peaking systolic murmur.

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be addressed:

1. Critical AS: The patient's severe DOE is likely due to critical AS, and he is awaiting valvuloplasty today. The patient's symptoms may worsen if the AS is not addressed promptly.
2. sCHF: The patient has a history of sCHF, and his current condition may exacerbate this condition. He is at risk of developing pulmonary edema and respiratory failure.
3. Afib: The patient has developed atrial fibrillation, which may be contributing to his SOB/DOE. This condition needs to be monitored and managed to prevent further complications.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be secondary to cirrhosis. Fluid restriction is necessary to prevent further electrolyte imbalances.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis, which increases his risk of bleeding and bleeding complications. He needs to be monitored for signs of bleeding and liver dysfunction.
6. DM2: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2, and his blood glucose levels need to be monitored and managed to prevent further complications.
7. HTN: The patient has a history of hypertension, which may be contributing to his current condition. He needs to be monitored for signs of hypertension and cardiovascular complications.
8. Diarrhea: The patient has a history of diarrhea, which may be secondary to C. difficile infection. He needs to be monitored for signs of infection and managed accordingly.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and hemodynamic parameters closely.
2. Manage the patient's critical AS with valvuloplasty today.
3. Monitor the patient's sCHF and manage it with diuresis and vasodilators as necessary.
4. Manage the patient's Afib with rate control and anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's hyponatremia and manage it with fluid restriction and electrolyte supplementation as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cirrhosis and manage it with vitamin K therapy and liver consult as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's DM2 and manage it with insulin and glucose monitoring as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's HTN and manage it with antihypertensive therapy as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's diarrhea and manage it with antibiotics and antidiarrheal agents as necessary.

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), and cirrhosis, was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypotension. He was found to have a valve area of 0.5 cmÂ² and a gradient of 60, consistent with critical AS. He was started on antibiotics empirically and lasix was given due to suspected fluid overload. The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a blood pressure of 81/52 mmHg, heart rate of 103 bpm, and respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. He is also experiencing atrial fibrillation and has guaiac-positive stools.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS is likely to worsen due to the valve area of 0.5 cmÂ² and the gradient of 60. This could lead to further hypotension, decreased cardiac output, and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and empiric antibiotics suggest the possibility of sepsis. This could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
3. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload, as evidenced by the lasix administration, could worsen his hypotension and increase his risk of cardiac failure.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation could lead to decreased cardiac output, increased risk of stroke, and decreased blood pressure.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stools suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to anemia, hypovolemic shock, and increased mortality.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute suggest respiratory failure, which could lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and increased mortality.
7. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's unstable vital signs and worsening cardiac function increase his risk of cardiac arrest, which could lead to decreased cardiac output, increased mortality, and poor outcomes.

Based on these findings, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management of his critical AS, fluid overload, and other potential complications to improve his outcomes.

   symptoms of severe DOE due to AS. Awaiting valvulplasty later on today.
   [**Month (only) 8**] have been overdiuresed yesterday leading to poor forward flow and
   subsequent hypotension. Although patient only put out 300 cc to lasix,

   shifts. BP has responded to small fluid bolus of 650 cc on the floor.
   -  Plan to hold off on further fluids. Goal MAP greater than 55.

   100.
   -Hold heparin gtt
   -active t and s

   - Continue dofetelide
   # Sepsis: Given diarrhea, Cdiff in differential. UA points to possible
   urinary source. Patient had previously reported a cough but may have
   been due to over hydration. Patient does meet sepsis criteria with
   positive UA, in addition to low grade fever, leukocytosis, increase RR,
   and tachycardia. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 226**] MS may be delirium.
   - Start empiric Vanco/Zosyn
   - Follow culture data
   - Will need central access
   - C diff

   of sepsis and critical AS.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds

   as CT abdomen. Pt hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. Pt had liver
   f/u as outpt for possible endoscopy and pre-op Child's classification
   and bleeding risk. Pt did have thombocytopenia and elevated INR on last

   Currently Albumin 3.4, Cr, Tbili normal. G positive stools may be due
   to upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal
   bleed.
   # DM

 NPO

 None right now
   # Code- DNR/I

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with sCHF exacerbation and worsening of AS. He has been experiencing persistent severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) due to critical AS. He was given lasix 20mg IV, which led to a 250cc diuresis, but his blood pressure decreased to 81/52mmHg, triggering hypotension. He was given 650cc of normal saline, and his blood pressure responded. He has been transferred to the CCU for further management of critical AS.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a positive UA, indicating a possible urinary source of infection. He has also reported a cough, which may be due to overhydration. He meets sepsis criteria with positive UA, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased respiratory rate, and tachycardia.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS may have contributed to acute renal failure.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he has a history of liver disease. His albumin level is 3.4, and his Cr is normal. He has had a history of thrombocytopenia and elevated INR on his last admission.
4. Diarrhea: The patient has had profuse diarrhea, which may have led to volume shifts and contributed to his hypotension.
5. New-onset atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, but it has recently become persistent. He has been treated with dofetilide and is being monitored for further arrhythmias.
6. Critical AS: The patient's critical AS is the primary cause of his symptoms, and he is awaiting valvuloplasty today.
7. C. difficile infection: The patient has guaiac-positive stools, which may indicate C. difficile infection.
8. Overdiuresis: The patient's recent diuresis may have led to poor forward flow and subsequent hypotension.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. The patient developed hypotension, likely due to overdiuresis and volume shifts, which responded to a small fluid bolus.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Critical AS: The patient has severe AS with a valve area of 0.5cm2, which is causing symptoms of severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE).
2. New-onset atrial fibrillation (AF): The patient was admitted with AF, which is being treated with rate control and anticoagulation.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a positive urine analysis (UA) with leukocytosis, tachycardia, and increased respiratory rate, which suggests a possible urinary source of sepsis.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are likely elevated due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, which may be contributing to his current condition.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB): The patient has brown stools, which may be due to an upper GIB, possibly caused by duodenitis or a duodenal ulcer.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's critical AS may lead to cardiac tamponade if the valve area becomes more severe.
2. Septic shock: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock if not properly managed.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not treated promptly.
4. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's GIB may worsen if not managed properly.
5. Sepsis-related organ failure: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ failure if not properly managed.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Valvuloplasty: The patient is scheduled for valvuloplasty to improve his AS.
2. Antibiotic therapy: The patient is receiving empiric antibiotics for sepsis.
3. Fluid management: The patient's fluid status will be closely monitored to prevent overdiuresis and volume shifts.
4. Cardiac monitoring: The patient's cardiac rhythm will be closely monitored to ensure rate control and anticoagulation.
5. Gastrointestinal management: The patient's GIB will be managed with anti-emetics, proton pump inhibitors, and possible endoscopy.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk patient with multiple medical complications, including critical AS, sepsis, acute renal failure, and GIB. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his clinical outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), systolic heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with exacerbation of systolic heart failure and worsening of aortic stenosis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) due to critical aortic stenosis. He has been treated with lasix 20mg IV, resulting in a 250cc output, but his blood pressure (BP) dropped to 81/52mmHg. He has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (AF) and is awaiting valvuloplasty today.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's symptoms of diarrhea, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, and tachycardia, he meets the criteria for sepsis. The differential diagnosis includes urinary tract infection, and the patient has been started on empiric Vanco/Zosyn.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical aortic stenosis may have contributed to acute renal failure. His creatinine levels will need to be trended, and medications will need to be renally dosed.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient's history of alcoholic cirrhosis may have contributed to his current condition. He has been diagnosed with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) and has been treated with pivs and IV ppi.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's AF may require cardioversion, and he has been started on dofetilide.
5. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical aortic stenosis requires valvuloplasty, which is scheduled for today.

The patient's current medications include lasix, Vanco/Zosyn, dofetilide, and heparin. He has been advised to hold off on further fluids and to continue his current medications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male admitted to the ICU with severe congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation and worsening of critical aortic stenosis (AS). The patient's condition has improved with phenylephrine infusion and fluid boluses.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical AS and CHF exacerbation put him at risk for further cardiac decompensation, including cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's symptoms of fever, leukocytosis, tachycardia, and tachypnea, along with a positive urinary antigen test, suggest sepsis. This may lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular instability.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's low urine output, elevated creatinine levels, and potential sepsis put him at risk for acute kidney injury, which may require renal replacement therapy.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of cirrhosis, upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and duodenitis increases the risk of further gastrointestinal bleeding, which may lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and hypoxemia put him at risk for respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
6. Thrombosis: The patient's history of cirrhosis and heparin use increases the risk of thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and potential sepsis increase the risk of delirium, which may lead to cognitive impairment, agitation, and increased risk of falls and other complications.

Given these potential complications, the patient's management plan should include:

1. Close monitoring of cardiac status, including cardiac enzymes and echocardiography.
2. Aggressive management of sepsis, including prompt administration of antibiotics and fluids.
3. Renal replacement therapy if acute kidney injury develops.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding prophylaxis, including stress ulcer prophylaxis and consideration of IV proton pump inhibitors.
5. Respiratory support, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary.
6. Thromboprophylaxis, including consideration of low-molecular-weight heparin or warfarin.
7. Delirium management, including sedation and analgesia as needed, and close monitoring for signs of worsening delirium.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was recently admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS. He is awaiting valvuloplasty and is currently complicated by sepsis, acute renal failure, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). The patient's condition has improved significantly since the placement of a cordis and the administration of phenylephrine, but he remains at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued sepsis: The patient's blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and his urine culture is growing coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. He is at risk for continued sepsis and bacteremia.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, and he is at risk for further deterioration in renal function.
3. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of GIB, and his current condition is consistent with an upper source of bleeding. He is at risk for continued bleeding and potential complications.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has critical AS and is at risk for further cardiac complications, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient has a central line in place, and he is at risk for infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
6. Thrombosis: The patient has a history of thrombosis, and he is at risk for further thrombotic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
7. Liver failure: The patient has cirrhosis, and he is at risk for further deterioration in liver function, including liver failure.
8. Respiratory complications: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is at risk for further respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient, a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. He was started on Dobutamine, but due to tachycardia, it was stopped and replaced with Phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg.

The patient's condition improved, and he was found to have a positive blood culture growing coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CNS) and a urine culture growing the same organism. The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) was 13.7 K/Î¼L, and his hemoglobin (Hb) was 13.8 g/dL. His creatinine (Cr) level increased to 1.8 mg/dL, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.

The patient's other laboratory results showed:

* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 3.9 mg/dL
* Alkaline phosphatase (ALK-PH): 53 U/L
* Total bilirubin (T-Bili): 3.0 mg/dL
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 113 U/L
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 43 U/L

The patient's physical examination revealed:

* General: ill appearing, lethargic but easily arousable
* Cardiovascular: regular rhythm, harsh late peaking semisternal murmur, no rubs or gallops
* Pulmonary: crackles at the right base
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, no organomegaly
* Extremities: 1+ edema 3 cm above ankle bilaterally, thready distal pulses

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood culture growing coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and urine culture growing the same organism indicate ongoing sepsis.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's increasing Cr level and decreased urine output suggest acute renal failure.
3. Critical aortic stenosis: The patient's critical AS is a significant risk factor for cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient's history of cirrhosis and recent hepatitis panel negative for Hep A, B, and C suggest that the patient may have chronic liver disease.
5. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB): The patient's history of duodenitis and recent EGD showing erythema and congestion in the first part of the duodenum suggest a possible upper source of GIB.
6. DVT: The patient's history of recent hospitalization and immobility increase the risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
7. VAP: The patient's presence in the ICU and recent intubation increase the risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening of AS, and is awaiting valvuloplasty.

The patient has developed sepsis with positive blood cultures growing coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and urine cultures growing coagulase-positive Staphylococcus. He has also developed acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL, and is likely experiencing upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) given his brown stools and Hct drop.

The patient is currently receiving treatment for his sepsis, including vancomycin and phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg. He is also receiving dopamine and dobutamine to support his cardiac output.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Worsening of AS leading to cardiac failure
	* Development of cardiac arrhythmias
	* Increased risk of endocarditis
2. Renal complications:
	* Progressive acute renal failure leading to end-stage renal disease
	* Increased risk of electrolyte imbalances
3. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Continued bleeding from the upper GI tract
	* Development of gastrointestinal perforation or obstruction
4. Infections:
	* Continued bacteremia and sepsis
	* Development of pneumonia or other secondary infections
5. Hemodynamic instability:
	* Continued tachycardia and hypertension
	* Development of hypotension or shock

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe congestive heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with a worsening exacerbation of congestive heart failure and was found to have a low cardiac output due to overdiuresis. He was treated with a small fluid bolus and phenylephrine to improve his blood pressure. He was also started on empiric antibiotics for suspected sepsis and is awaiting valvuloplasty.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Worsening of congestive heart failure due to overdiuresis
	* Decreased cardiac output due to critical aortic stenosis
	* Potential for cardiac arrhythmias due to sepsis and critical AS
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute renal failure due to poor forward flow and sepsis
	* Potential for worsening of renal function due to continued sepsis and critical AS
3. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to duodenitis and possible variceal bleed
	* Potential for worsening of bleeding due to continued sepsis and critical AS
4. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis due to suspected urinary tract infection and possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Potential for worsening of sepsis due to continued sepsis and critical AS
5. Respiratory Complications:
	* Potential for worsening of respiratory failure due to sepsis and critical AS
6. Hematological Complications:
	* Potential for worsening of anemia due to continued bleeding and sepsis
7. Neurological Complications:
	* Potential for worsening of delirium due to sepsis and critical AS

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and medical treatment to prevent or manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS, awaiting valvuloplasty. He developed sepsis with coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CoNS) bacteremia, and his condition was complicated by acute renal failure (ARF) and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 83 beats per minute, blood pressure of 93/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%. His respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen delivery.

Physical examination reveals a patient who is ill-appearing, lethargic, but easily arousable. His cardiovascular examination shows regular rhythm, harsh late-peaking systolic murmur, and no rubs or gallops. His pulmonary examination reveals crackles at the right base. His abdominal examination shows mild ascites, and his extremities show 1+ edema 3 cm above the ankle bilaterally.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 38.7%
* Platelet count: 86 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 34 mg/dL
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is being treated with vancomycin, and his condition should be closely monitored for signs of worsening sepsis.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's ARF is likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS. His creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen level is 34 mg/dL. His fluid intake should be limited, and his medications should be renally dosed.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's GIB is likely due to upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and his hemoglobin level is 13.7 g/dL. He should be closely monitored for signs of bleeding, and his blood pressure should be closely monitored to prevent further bleeding.
4. Critical aortic stenosis: The patient's critical AS is being treated with phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure greater than 55 mmHg. His valvuloplasty is scheduled for later this week.
5. New-onset atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation is being treated with dofetilide, and his cardioversion is planned for later this week.
6. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis is likely due to his history of alcohol use, and his liver function tests are elevated. He should be closely monitored for signs of worsening liver dysfunction.
7. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration is a concern, and he should be closely monitored for signs of aspiration pneumonia.
8. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's DM is being treated with insulin, and his blood glucose level is 101 mg/dL. He should be closely monitored for signs of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening AS. He has been overdiuresed, leading to poor forward flow and subsequent hypotension. He has also developed new-onset atrial fibrillation (A-fib) and sepsis, likely due to a urinary source. He has acute renal failure (ARF) and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with a possible upper GI source.

Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has met sepsis criteria with positive urinalysis, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased respiratory rate, and tachycardia. He has been started on empiric vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has developed ARF likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS. Renal dosing of medications and urine electrolyte monitoring are necessary.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has GIB with a possible upper GI source. He has been started on proton pump inhibitors and may require reconsultation with GI services.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has developed new-onset A-fib and is being treated with dofetilide. Cardioversion is planned.
5. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient has critical AS with a valve area of 0.5 cm2. He is awaiting valvuloplasty today.
6. Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis likely due to previous ethanol use. He has been diagnosed with duodenitis and may have upper GI bleeding.
7. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient has DM and may be at risk for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) given his recent admission and treatment with insulin.

Plan:

1. Hold off on further fluids and monitor the patient's blood pressure.
2. Plan for valvuloplasty today.
3. Continue empiric antibiotics for sepsis.
4. Trend creatinine and urine electrolytes.
5. Monitor for signs of DKA and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
6. Consider reconsultation with GI services for further management of GIB.
7. Monitor for signs of worsening cardiac function and adjust treatment as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening AS. The patient has been experiencing severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) due to critical AS and is awaiting valvuloplasty. He has been overdiuresed, leading to poor forward flow and subsequent hypotension. The patient has developed new-onset atrial fibrillation (A fib) and is being treated with rate control medication.

The patient has also developed sepsis, likely due to a urinary source, with a positive urine culture and leukocytosis. He has acute renal failure, likely due to poor forward flow and sepsis. The patient has cirrhosis and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). He has been treated with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and is being monitored for signs of GIB.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to progress if not treated, leading to further fluid accumulation and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's risk of GIB is high due to his cirrhosis and history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's A fib is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further cardiac complications and increased risk of mortality.
5. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS is likely to worsen if not treated with valvuloplasty, leading to further cardiac complications and increased risk of mortality.
6. Sepsis-Induced Cardiomyopathy: The patient's sepsis is likely to induce cardiomyopathy, leading to further cardiac dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
7. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis is at risk for hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to altered mental status and increased risk of mortality.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further respiratory complications and increased risk of mortality.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was admitted with sCHF exacerbation and worsening of AS. He is awaiting valvuloplasty. The patient has been overdiuresed, leading to hypotension, and has been given a small fluid bolus. His current symptoms include severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) due to critical AS. He has new-onset atrial fibrillation (A fib) and is being treated with dofetilide. The patient has also developed sepsis, likely due to a urinary source, and acute renal failure. He has a history of cirrhosis and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). He has been started on empiric vancomycin and Zosyn and will need central access.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to a urinary source, and it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs and lab results to ensure that the infection does not worsen.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS. It is essential to continue monitoring his creatinine levels and adjust his medications accordingly.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GIB): The patient's history of cirrhosis and recent diarrhea increase his risk for GIB. It is essential to monitor his stool output and consider upper endoscopy to rule out variceal bleeding.
4. Critical Aortic Stenosis (AS): The patient's critical AS is the underlying cause of his symptoms, and it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs and lab results to ensure that his condition does not worsen.
5. Atrial Fibrillation (A fib): The patient's new-onset A fib is being treated with dofetilide, but it is essential to continue monitoring his cardiac rhythm and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
6. Sepsis-Related Organ Dysfunction (SOFA): The patient's sepsis is likely to cause SOFA, which can lead to organ dysfunction and poor outcomes. It is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs and lab results to ensure that his condition does not worsen.

Summary:

The patient is an 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. He has been treated for sepsis caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and has undergone antibiotic therapy. He is awaiting valvuloplasty to improve his systemic perfusion.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. His respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen delivery.

The patient's physical examination reveals a weak and lethargic individual with a temperature of 36.2Â°C (97.1Â°F). He has a regular heart rhythm and a blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg. His abdomen is soft and non-tender, and he has 1+ edema 3 cm above the ankle bilaterally.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 38.7 g/L
* Platelet count: 86 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mmol/L
* Glucose: 122 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* LDH: 292 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.4 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has been treated for sepsis caused by MRSA, and there is a risk of relapse.
2. Critical AS: The patient has critical AS, which can lead to heart failure and death if left untreated.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has improved, but there is still a risk of acute renal failure.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hypovolemic hyponatremia, which can lead to seizures and coma if left untreated.
5. Aspiration: The patient has a risk of aspiration due to his weak and lethargic state.
6. Anxiety and pain: The patient has anxiety and pain, which can be managed with medication.
7. DM: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which can lead to complications such as kidney disease and blindness if left untreated.
8. Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis, which can lead to liver failure and death if left untreated.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for sepsis.
2. Proceed with balloon valvuloplasty to improve systemic perfusion.
3. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
4. Manage the patient's anxiety and pain with medication.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's creatinine level and adjust dosing of renally cleared medications as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider a swallow evaluation once the patient is no longer NPO.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-inch tall male with a chief complaint of none. He is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, ineffective coping, atrial fibrillation, dysphagia, acute renal failure, aortic stenosis, bacteremia, anemia secondary to blood loss, and thrombocytopenia. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2Â°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. He is receiving vasopressor support and has a central venous pressure of 15 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and decreased platelet count. His liver enzymes are elevated, and his kidney function is impaired. He has a history of aortic stenosis, and his recent echocardiogram shows mild heart failure.

The patient is receiving antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and vasopressor support. His medication list includes vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, metronidazole, and doxycycline. He is also receiving corticosteroids and antihistamines.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is not improving, and there is a risk of developing organ dysfunction, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's kidney function is impaired, and there is a risk of developing AKI, which can lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalance and acidosis.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreased, and there is a risk of developing bleeding complications, such as petechiae, ecchymosis, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is secondary to blood loss, and there is a risk of developing further complications, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is not controlled, and there is a risk of developing further complications, such as stroke, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or surgical site infection.
7. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia make him at risk of developing bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.
8. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac condition and medication regimen make him at risk of developing cardiac arrest.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and there is a risk of developing respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS. He developed sepsis, and bacteria were identified as methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). The patient is awaiting valvuloplasty and has been managed with vancomycin, phenylephrine, and doetilide. He has also developed hyponatremia, acute renal failure, and cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has developed sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and decreased cardiac output.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure can progress to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia can lead to seizures, coma, and even death if not treated promptly and effectively.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis can lead to liver failure, portal hypertension, and increased risk of bleeding.
6. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration risk is high due to his decreased level of consciousness and inability to protect his airway.
7. Anxiety and Pain: The patient's anxiety and pain can lead to increased heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate, which can exacerbate his underlying medical conditions.
8. DVT: The patient's DVT risk is high due to his immobility and central venous catheter.
9. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk is high due to his cirrhosis and anticoagulation therapy.
10. Infection: The patient's infection risk is high due to his sepsis and central venous catheter.

These potential medical complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's condition to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS, and is awaiting valvuloplasty. The patient has developed sepsis, likely due to methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, and has been treated with vancomycin. He has also developed hyponatremia, acute renal failure, and cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to organ failure and death.
2. Critical AS: The patient's critical AS is likely to worsen if not treated with valvuloplasty, leading to further cardiac compromise and death.
3. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to seizures, coma, and death.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to end-stage renal disease and death.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to liver failure and death.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to hemorrhagic shock and death.
7. Aspiration: The patient's aspiration is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to pneumonia and death.
8. DVT: The patient's DVT is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to pulmonary embolism and death.
9. Stress Ulcer: The patient's stress ulcer is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding and death.
10. VAP: The patient's VAP is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to pneumonia and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for sepsis.
2. Perform valvuloplasty as soon as possible to treat critical AS.
3. Treat hyponatremia with fluid and electrolyte replacement.
4. Continue renal replacement therapy for acute renal failure.
5. Treat cirrhosis with lactulose and rifaximin.
6. Monitor gastrointestinal bleeding and treat with antacids and proton pump inhibitors.
7. Monitor aspiration and treat with suction and antibiotics.
8. Monitor DVT and treat with anticoagulation.
9. Monitor stress ulcer and treat with antacids and proton pump inhibitors.
10. Monitor VAP and treat with antibiotics and mechanical ventilation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. The patient is awaiting valvuloplasty and has been complicated by sepsis.

Current medical issues:

1. Critical AS: The patient's valve area is 0.5 cm2, and he is awaiting palliative valvuloplasty while his bacteremia clears.
2. New onset atrial fibrillation (A fib): The patient was noted to have A fib on admission, and cardioversion was planned. However, due to a drop in hemoglobin, heparin was discontinued, and anticoagulation was held.
3. Sepsis: The patient's urine culture is growing coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and his blood cultures are growing coagulase-positive Staphylococcus. He has no peripheral manifestations of endocarditis, and his transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) is negative for vegetations.
4. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine (Cr) level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL from 1.6 mg/dL yesterday, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of alcohol use, and his liver function tests (LFTs) are increased likely due to shock liver. He has also been experiencing gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) and may have an upper source of bleeding.
6. Aspiration: The patient reports coughing with thin liquids, and a swallow evaluation has been deferred while he is NPO.
7. DM: The patient's blood glucose levels are not well-controlled.

Potential medical complications:

1. Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy and decreased platelet count.
2. Further deterioration of renal function, potentially leading to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
3. Development of septic shock, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
4. Increased risk of GIB, which could lead to further blood loss and hemodynamic instability.
5. Potential for cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, which could worsen his heart failure.
6. Possible development of endocarditis, which could lead to further complications and increased risk of mortality.
7. Increased risk of pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status.

Plan:

1. Continue phenylephrine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg.
2. Monitor the patient's volume status closely and adjust fluid intake accordingly.
3. Continue vancomycin, but change to once-daily dosing, and discontinue Zosyn.
4. Check vancomycin levels and follow culture data.
5. Repeat C. difficile testing.
6. Trend Cr levels and adjust medications accordingly.
7. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and adjust medications as needed.
8. Consider referring the patient to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of his GIB.
9. Monitor the patient's DM and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was recently admitted with sCHF exacerbation and worsening of AS. He is awaiting valvuloplasty. The patient's course has been complicated by sepsis, acute renal failure, and cirrhosis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5Â°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 98% on nasal cannula. He is receiving phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.7, hemoglobin of 13.5 g/dL, and creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, and his platelet count is 86,000/Î¼L.

The patient's medical conditions include critical AS, sCHF, cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He has a history of alcohol use, but has reportedly stopped drinking approximately one year ago.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Worsening of AS and sCHF
	* Potential for cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest
2. Renal complications:
	* Acute renal failure
	* Potential for further decline in renal function
3. Infection complications:
	* Sepsis
	* Potential for bacteremia and endocarditis
4. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB)
	* Potential for further bleeding and gastrointestinal perforation
5. Respiratory complications:
	* Potential for respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
6. Neurological complications:
	* Potential for seizures and cerebral edema due to sepsis and liver dysfunction

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue phenylephrine to maintain a MAP greater than 55 mmHg.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
3. Continue vancomycin and change to once-daily dosing.
4. Trend the patient's creatinine level and adjust medication dosing as necessary.
5. Consider consulting a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of upper GIB.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider consulting a neurologist for further evaluation and management of potential neurological complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS, and later developed MSSA sepsis. He underwent aortic valvuloplasty and percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) to the right coronary artery (RCA) on [**2168-6-9**]. The patient remains in the ICU with ongoing medical management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MSSA bacteremia may progress to sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Critical AS: The patient's critical AS may worsen, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased pulmonary artery pressure, and potential for cardiac arrest.
3. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if fluid management is not optimized, leading to seizures, coma, or even death.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or even require dialysis.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of cirrhosis and positive stools for G positive bacteria may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Aspiration: The patient's coughing with thin liquids may lead to aspiration, which could result in pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
7. Anxiety/Pain: The patient's anxiety and pain may worsen post-procedure, leading to increased stress and potential for complications.
8. DM: The patient's diabetes mellitus may require close monitoring and management to prevent complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or ketoacidosis.
9. Access: The patient's right Cordis with IJ access may need to be replaced due to bacteremia, which could lead to further complications.
10. VAP: The patient's risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) may increase due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation and underlying medical conditions.

These potential complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's medical conditions to prevent or minimize adverse outcomes.

Summary:

The patient underwent an aortic valvuloplasty procedure, which was successful in reducing the peak valve gradient. However, the patient remains in atrial fibrillation with a controlled heart rate. The patient has hyponatremia, which is being managed with normal saline instead of D5W. The patient's creatinine level has improved, and the dose of dofetilide may need to be increased if the creatinine level remains stable or improves.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient has bacteremia, and the culture results are pending. The patient is at risk for developing sepsis, septic shock, or organ dysfunction.
2. Bleeding: The patient had scant bleeding at the catheter site, and bruising is marked. The patient is at risk for developing bleeding complications, including hematoma or hemorrhage.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may worsen if the patient's creatinine level continues to rise.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or stroke.
5. Respiratory Complications: The patient has hyponatremia, which may lead to respiratory complications, including respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has anemia, which may lead to neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, or encephalopathy.
7. Thrombotic Complications: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which may lead to thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, or stroke.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has dysphagia, which may lead to gastrointestinal complications, including aspiration pneumonia, malnutrition, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their condition to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis. He is diagnosed with sepsis caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia. The patient underwent aortic valvuloplasty and placement of two bare-metal stents in the right coronary artery. He remains in atrial fibrillation and has hyponatremia, acute renal failure, and cirrhosis with positive stool tests for G-positive stools. The patient's condition is complicated by sepsis, critical AS, and cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to multi-organ failure, if not properly managed.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's bacteremia may lead to endocarditis, which can cause heart valve damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis if not managed properly.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen, leading to seizures, coma, or even death if not properly managed.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to stroke or other cardiovascular complications if not managed properly.
6. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen, leading to liver failure, if not properly managed.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's cirrhosis and positive stool tests for G-positive stools may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Infection: The patient's bacteremia may lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, if not properly managed.
9. Respiratory Failure: The patient's sepsis and atrial fibrillation may lead to respiratory failure if not properly managed.
10. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's critical AS and sepsis may lead to cardiac arrest if not properly managed.

   ------ Protected Section ------
   SUB-INTERN ADDENDUM
   Assessment:
   79 y/o M with critical AS, CHF (EF40%), alcoholic cirrhosis, DM,
   admitted for worsening DOE, out from septic shock, now recorvering from
   valvuloplasty.
   # Septic shock.  His shock was caused by MSSA as identified by blood
   and urine cultures on [**6-6**]. Surveillance cultures were still positive
   on [**6-7**] but on [**6-8**] and [**6-9**] have been NGTD. Based on sensitivities he
   was started on nafcillin on [**6-8**] and he is now day 2 of 14 and he is
   now afebrile with a stable white count.  He is over the acute phase of
   his sepsis as his MAPs are increasing with lower doses of phenylephrine
   (today at 0.4) and with a net positive fluid balance of only about 500
   cc yesterday. We can continue to wean him off the phenylephrine and
   keep his fluid balance even as he is becoming more hemodynamically
   stable.
   #CHF.  The patient has a history of CHF with EF of 45%, but upon the
   start of his sepsis he had an EF of 20%. This most likely was due to a
   stunned myocardium that resulted from increased work and stress to
   maintain sufficient cardiac output against his dropping blood pressure
   (from sepsis) as well as the extremely large gradient across his aortic
   valve due to his severe aortic stenosis. Now that his septic shock is
   nearly over, his CHF should improve and we should see an improvement in
   his pulmonary and peripheral edema. However, because of his severe
   aortic stenosis and his low baseline ejection fraction, he will always
   have some level of edema even if he diurese him. In fact, if we diurese
   him too much he will become intravascularly depleted
 and that
   exactly what happened as evidenced by his rising creatinine (ARF due to
   insufficient blood flow to kidney), highly concentrated urine (U-osm
   600 and U-Na <10), and hyponatremia (since he was intravascularly
   depleted, his pituitary made more ADH to hold onto free water which
   caused dilution of his Na). At this point we will allow him to slowly
   replete volume (0 to 500cc positive) as we want to be careful not to
   cause too much pulmonary edema that he would need a ventilator since he
   is DNI. In the long term, we will soon restart his out-patient CHF
   therapy, including a beta blocker, ace inhibitor, possibly lasix, and
   aldactone. He will probably need an echo as an outpatient as well to
   determine if his EF is getting better.
   #Aortic stenosis.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Hospital 6402**] Medical
   Student  on:[**2168-6-10**] 13:36 ------
   # Aortic stenosis.  Yesterday he had aortic valvuloplasty that managed
   to decrease his aortic valve pressure gradient from approximately 60 mm
   Hg to 50 mm Hg. According to the Hakki equation, Aortic Valve Area
   (cm^2) = cardiac output (L/min) / sqrt (valve pressure gradient [mm Hg]
   ). His pre-procedure aortic valve area, given a pressure gradient of 60
   mm Hg and an estimated cardiac output of 4L/min, was approximately
   *0.52 cm*. Given his new gradient of approximately 50 mm Hg, his
   post-procedure aortic valve area is *0.57 cm* (normal aortic valve is
   >2cm). The procedure was not successful in significantly increasing his
   aortic valve area most likely because the valve was very calcific and
   hard to open. The procedure that is most likely to eliminate his aortic
   stenosis is valve replacement. However, because the patient knows that
   he is at the end of his life, he wants to have minimal additional
   procedures and does not want to undergo this kind of major operation.
   Therefore, at this time we will manage his aortic stenosis as best as
   we can with cautious and conservative medical management.
   # CAD.  During the valvuloplasty yesterday, the patient was found to
   have approximately 90% stenosis of his right coronary artery. As a
   result, 2 bare metal stents were placed and he was loaded with
   clopidogrel. Due to the high risk of clot developing on the stent, the
   patient needs to be started on clopidogrel for at least one month and a
   full dose of aspirin. Since stenosis of the coronary arteries is most
   often due to cholesterol plaques, we should evaluate his lipids with a
   full lipid panel and start him on a high dose statin (probably
   simvastatin because it is cheap and probably as effective as
   atorvastatin). Otherwise, a beta-blocker could be added in the future
   to decrease strain on the heart and decrease the risk of acute coronary
   syndrome.
   # Afib.  The patient is written for dofetilide for rhythm control of
   his atrial fibrillation. We can increase his dose to 250 mg [**Hospital1 **] since
   he is no longer in renal failure. In terms of anti-coagulation, this is
   going to be an important issue to discuss with the patient himself. His
   risk of developing a clot and embolus resulting in stroke is very high
   (CHADS2 score gives him an 8.5% chance of stroke in the following year,
   and his catheterization procedure also increases his stroke risk).
   Logically we would like to start this patient on some aggressive
   anti-coagulation. However, we have to balance the stroke risk against
   his risk of massive hemorrhage. His bleed risk is low, however, since
   he is unlikely to have any falls (he is mostly immobile), he does not
   have hypertension that would lead to intracranial hemorrhage, and his
   only risk factor is a past history of GI bleed. We have to weigh all of
   these choices with the patient
s goals of care.
   # Other problems. The patients other problems are as outlines above.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Hospital 6402**] Medical
   Student  on:[**2168-6-10**] 14:09 ------
   14:09
   I have reviewed the progress note by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3237**] on [**2168-6-10**].  I
   concur with the history and physical examination over the past 24 hours
   documented above.   The examination is consistent with my examination
   today.   Balloon aortic valvulopasty yesterday resulted in a modest
   improvement of his aortic valve gradient and stenting of his RCA using
   a bare metal stent.    We have reviewed the prognosis with the patient
   and will continue to discuss additional therapeutic plans with the
   patient over the next several days.   [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 3051**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6109**], MD  [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6129**]

   ------ Protected Section ------
   SUB-INTERN ADDENDUM
   Assessment:
   79 y/o M with critical AS, CHF (EF40%), alcoholic cirrhosis, DM,
   admitted for worsening DOE, out from septic shock, now recorvering from
   valvuloplasty.
   # Septic shock.  His shock was caused by MSSA as identified by blood
   and urine cultures on [**6-6**]. Surveillance cultures were still positive
   on [**6-7**] but on [**6-8**] and [**6-9**] have been NGTD. Based on sensitivities he
   was started on nafcillin on [**6-8**] and he is now day 2 of 14 and he is
   now afebrile with a stable white count.  He is over the acute phase of
   his sepsis as his MAPs are increasing with lower doses of phenylephrine
   (today at 0.4) and with a net positive fluid balance of only about 500
   cc yesterday. We can continue to wean him off the phenylephrine and
   keep his fluid balance even as he is becoming more hemodynamically
   stable.
   #CHF.  The patient has a history of CHF with EF of 45%, but upon the
   start of his sepsis he had an EF of 20%. This most likely was due to a
   stunned myocardium that resulted from increased work and stress to
   maintain sufficient cardiac output against his dropping blood pressure
   (from sepsis) as well as the extremely large gradient across his aortic
   valve due to his severe aortic stenosis. Now that his septic shock is
   nearly over, his CHF should improve and we should see an improvement in
   his pulmonary and peripheral edema. However, because of his severe
   aortic stenosis and his low baseline ejection fraction, he will always
   have some level of edema even if he diurese him. In fact, if we diurese
   him too much he will become intravascularly depleted
 and that
   exactly what happened as evidenced by his rising creatinine (ARF due to
   insufficient blood flow to kidney), highly concentrated urine (U-osm
   600 and U-Na <10), and hyponatremia (since he was intravascularly
   depleted, his pituitary made more ADH to hold onto free water which
   caused dilution of his Na). At this point we will allow him to slowly
   replete volume (0 to 500cc positive) as we want to be careful not to
   cause too much pulmonary edema that he would need a ventilator since he
   is DNI. In the long term, we will soon restart his out-patient CHF
   therapy, including a beta blocker, ace inhibitor, possibly lasix, and
   aldactone. He will probably need an echo as an outpatient as well to
   determine if his EF is getting better.
   #Aortic stenosis.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Hospital 6402**] Medical
   Student  on:[**2168-6-10**] 13:36 ------
   # Aortic stenosis.  Yesterday he had aortic valvuloplasty that managed
   to decrease his aortic valve pressure gradient from approximately 60 mm
   Hg to 50 mm Hg. According to the Hakki equation, Aortic Valve Area
   (cm^2) = cardiac output (L/min) / sqrt (valve pressure gradient [mm Hg]
   ). His pre-procedure aortic valve area, given a pressure gradient of 60
   mm Hg and an estimated cardiac output of 4L/min, was approximately
   *0.52 cm*. Given his new gradient of approximately 50 mm Hg, his
   post-procedure aortic valve area is *0.57 cm* (normal aortic valve is
   >2cm). The procedure was not successful in significantly increasing his
   aortic valve area most likely because the valve was very calcific and
   hard to open. The procedure that is most likely to eliminate his aortic
   stenosis is valve replacement. However, because the patient knows that
   he is at the end of his life, he wants to have minimal additional
   procedures and does not want to undergo this kind of major operation.
   Therefore, at this time we will manage his aortic stenosis as best as
   we can with cautious and conservative medical management.
   # CAD.  During the valvuloplasty yesterday, the patient was found to
   have approximately 90% stenosis of his right coronary artery. As a
   result, 2 bare metal stents were placed and he was loaded with
   clopidogrel. Due to the high risk of clot developing on the stent, the
   patient needs to be started on clopidogrel for at least one month and a
   full dose of aspirin. Since stenosis of the coronary arteries is most
   often due to cholesterol plaques, we should evaluate his lipids with a
   full lipid panel and start him on a high dose statin (probably
   simvastatin because it is cheap and probably as effective as
   atorvastatin). Otherwise, a beta-blocker could be added in the future
   to decrease strain on the heart and decrease the risk of acute coronary
   syndrome.
   # Afib.  The patient is written for dofetilide for rhythm control of
   his atrial fibrillation. We can increase his dose to 250 mg [**Hospital1 **] since
   he is no longer in renal failure. In terms of anti-coagulation, this is
   going to be an important issue to discuss with the patient himself. His
   risk of developing a clot and embolus resulting in stroke is very high
   (CHADS2 score gives him an 8.5% chance of stroke in the following year,
   and his catheterization procedure also increases his stroke risk).
   Logically we would like to start this patient on some aggressive
   anti-coagulation. However, we have to balance the stroke risk against
   his risk of massive hemorrhage. His bleed risk is low, however, since
   he is unlikely to have any falls (he is mostly immobile), he does not
   have hypertension that would lead to intracranial hemorrhage, and his
   only risk factor is a past history of GI bleed. We have to weigh all of
   these choices with the patient
s goals of care.
   # Other problems. The patients other problems are as outlines above.
